titleStmt.title: A Guide to the United States’ History of Recognition, Diplomatic, and Consular Relations, by Country, since 1776: Cabo Verde (Cape Verde)
Cabo Verde

sourceDesc.p: Researched and written by Chris Morrison, February 2009

div.head: Summary
div.p: The United States recognized the Republic of Cape Verde on July 5, 1975, when President Gerald R. Ford sent a letter to that effect to President Aristides Pereria.

div.head: U.S. Recognition of Cape Verde, 1975.
div.p: The United States recognized the Republic of Cape Verde on July 5, 1975, when President Gerald R. Ford sent a letter to that effect to President Aristides Pereria. Cape Verde previously had been under Portuguese sovereignty. In 2013, the country was re-named Cabo Verde.

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations, 1975.
div.p: Diplomatic relations were established on July 19, 1975, when Ambassador of the Republic of Cape Verde Raul Querido Varela presented his credentials to President Gerald R. Ford.

div.head: Accreditation of American Ambassador to Cape Verde, 1976.
div.p: Ambassador Melissa F. Wells presented her credentials to the government of Cape Verde on November 18, 1976. Wells also was accredited to Guinea-Bissau and was resident at Bissau.

div.head: Establishment of American Embassy in Cape Verde, 1978.
div.p: The American Embassy at Praia was established on January 28, 1978, with Howard McGowan as Charge d’Affaires ad interim.
